timeline.bodyText: i'm not sure if this is the right abstraction. The design of orc encryption doesn't have the concept of intermediate key. All it has is that there is provider, and the implementation of provider may choose to have intermediate key, or something else. Ideally this should be behind some interface. In bbio/dwio, we introduce factory which hold the set of keys, and can create encryption provider with the right key attached to it. We have crypto service factory that works with crypto service and can implement other factory when needed

replies.bodyText:
What spark/bbio and table service implemented is:

read partition metadata, for all the columns read, get the list of key references
call encryption library to get IEKs. This steps results in list
make this available to worker
worker creates a crypto service factory (which creates actual decrypter/encrypter). That factory will be initialized with the keys
the reader will basically call the factory to create the actual decrypter.

So the reader interface is very clean
reader(whatever that is already being passed in, decrypterFactory)
decrypterFactory is interface and can have cryptoServiceFactory, unknownFactory (for testing), etc.
https://www.internalfb.com/intern/diffusion/FBS/browse/master/fbcode/fbjava/bbio/hive-dwrf/src/main/java/com/facebook/hive/orc/OrcFile.java?commit=3e2b419b3e5b53f329c25af5a7a05d53f58292e1&lines=167
then the crypto impl:
https://www.internalfb.com/intern/diffusion/FBS/browse/master/fbcode/fbjava/bbio/hive-dwrf-encryption-provider/src/main/java/com/facebook/hive/orc/encryption/CryptoServiceDecrypterFactory.java?commit=58a1df82724fa93e8bd55b3c1e5bd07579ae65d6&lines=21

timeline.bodyText:
Where does presto handle schema mismatch?
day 1: table has struct<a:struct<a:int>, b:float> and we create a partition
day 2: table has new field appended to the first column: struct<a:struct<a:int,b:int>, b:float>, we create another partition
then int -> key map is not stable since same id represents different columns in the partition. Also FBETL has bug so not only that table schema may be different from partition's, partition schema may be different from the partition file. I did not see a place where it's explicitly handled

replies.bodyText: I saw this comment before your other one.  I didn't realize the orc column numbers wouldn't be stable (i knew you could add new columns, but didn't realize you could add new fields to row types so that the column numbers would be off). I guess an interface is the way to go
replies.author: rschlussel

replies.bodyText:
So basically i'm not sure about how Presto does schema mismatch. BBIO and DWIO do things differently for example. You solution may be different.
BBIO doesn't handle schema mismatch in the reader, it will always relies on the upper layer to handle it (object inspector craziness in the hive/spark context). So it can always load the node ids without worrying about a new key being added.
DWIO is different in the sense that the reader takes in the table schema, and then tries to match the file schema to it (assuming they are compatible). That step may case file level node id to be changed to match the table, hence id is not stable. So the reader maintains new id to old id map, and does one level of indirection to load the keys.
But regardless i think interface with integer id should be avoided. The contract is too loose and we should not use id to look up the key. In fact, the keyMetadata section stored key reference. BBIO loads all the keys specified in partition metadata to map<keyRef, IEK>, then the reader should just use keyMetadata to look up the actual IEK
replies.author: zzhao0

replies.bodyText: actually, I'm going to keep this map, but moving it to the record reader constructor.  We will generate the correct column indices before passing it in based on the column handle.  Also, note that the slice here isn't necessarily an intermediate key, it's whatever serialized metadata is required for reading.  The reason we can't just pass in the keyMetadata is because it's not defined that the key is sufficient to determine what the right iek is. if the keyMetadata is just an encrypted key, we'd need the field index to figure out what iek to use to decrypt it.

timeline.author: rschlussel

replies.bodyText:
stats are serialized very similar to the encoding and streams, ie. stats for the same encryption groups are put into the same FileStatistics object, and serialize with encryption. Then stored as blob inside the encryption group.
https://www.internalfb.com/intern/diffusion/FBS/browse/master/fbcode/fbjava/bbio/hive-dwrf/proto/orc_proto.proto?commit=f872cc50345082c014885fc81da222524985a30a&lines=191
if you have schema
struct<a:array, b:struct<a:int,b:int>, c:int>
a and b.b is in group 1
b.a is in group 2
c is not encrypted
you would expect to have:
encryption group 1:
nodes: a, b.b
stats: [a, a.elements, b.b]. (stats is nested)
stats for group2:
nodes:b.a
stats: [b.a]
two things to call out:


stats should be ordered the same way as the node. In group1, we have a as the first node, so we should have all stats for the subtree of a listed in front of all others. Alternatively, we can order it like:
nodes: b.b, a
stats: [b.b, a, a.elements]
reader should still be able to load it. But it's actually easier for writer to write a first...


file level stats is a list and is implicitly ordered according to schema. So for encrypted nodes, we still need to have one entry in the list except that it should not contain any detailed stats info (min/max/sum), it's ok to have value count and has null


on the reader side, it should merge stats from two places, and present user with a consistent view

Add metadata support for encrypted DWRF files

Make columnEncodings into a map

When dwrf encryption support is added, we can't rely on list position
of the encoding to be the same as the column index because encodings
for encrypted columns will be stored separately in the StripeEncryptionGroups,
and the reader may not even have access to them if the user doesn't have
the key for those groups. Instead we explicitly map the column index to the
correct encoding.

Move creation of includedOrcColumns to RecordReader

This will allow us to check in the recordReader whether the user has
keys for all the columns they are trying to access
